bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 7, 1901

div1.p: Reed discusses finances, and Emilie Lawrence Reed's loneliness. He reviews logistical questions regarding her possible visit to Cuba, and teases her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 7, 1901
div1.p:
If you
ever write me another let-
ter like the one you wrote
on January 3rd, I really don't
know what I will do with
you! How could you begin
your letter, “it is with hu-
miliation & sorrow that I
enclose B's & my expenses”!
Did a body ever hear of
such a thing? what was
the matter with your
darling expenses? I did-
n't see anything wrong
in them! I had supposed
that with Johnnie Moore's
bills, your December expenses
would be not less than
$330.00, and am very glad to
find that they have only
been $290.28. I think that
considering the Christmas
Holidays, you have managed
splendidly, my precious heart!
But suppose your expenses
had been $390.28, would
that have been any reason
for getting blue and being
distressed? For Heaven's
sake, dear Miss Gouty, don't
write that way any more,
or I shall get dreadfully
provoked- After putting
$953.00 in improvements
on our darling home,
we have saved- $700.00 during
the year- Instead of being
gloomy over that, I think
we should be well satis-
fied- We can't save all
of our income, sweetheart!
Why, bless your darling heart
you know that I am not
the kind of man to denyy my
sweet girls a few articles
of clothing, when these things
are necessary- Why didn't
you get more flowers for
your room and some present
for yourself- Do pray go to
the theatre just when you
want to and take fat Miss
Annapolis with you!
You will find that January's
expenses will be less, and then
I hope that you will brace
up a little bit. It wasn't
necessary that my darling
wifie should write out
in detail all that you
spent- You must have had
a dreadful headache after
doing that- I am so sorry
that your new year's was
such a lonely day- I think
my sweetheart, that you bor-
row too much trouble when
there is no reason for it-
I had thought that when
I was away, you remained
always so cheerful! He! he!
Brace up Miss Gouty!
Never mind about your
husband being famous-
Just drop that and attend
to your own darling self-
I hope that my letter, written
on the last night of the old
Century, cheered you up a
wee t bit- You dont know how
proud I am of my sweet wifie
and daughter, and I am proud
of that boy, too! And so is his
mother- Tuesday night - 8th-
I couldn't get any chance to
write any to-day on my letter.
Had to go to the Camp, this
morning, and this afternoon,
drove into Havana to make
my party call on Gen. & Mrs.
Wood. Tuesday is her day
from 3 to 5 P.M- Mrs. Wood
really looked very pretty,
and her manner is so un-
affected that it does
one good to meet such a
person and pass a few
words- Dearest heart! I
am so sorry that I cannot
advise you to take that
sea-voyage at this season
of the year. Dr McConnell
has just arrived, to-day, by
Transport, and he says that
it was so cold in New
York and that the trip down
was dreadfully rough-
I couldn't let my precious
wifie come unless I could
be with you, and then I
would be of no possible use.
It makes me very un-
happy to know that you
want to come so badly
and that I can't approve
of it- If you were already
here, we could manage
to get along, but it is the
getting here that is so very
troublesome- You can't im-
agine how I have worried
for the last few days, since
I got your letter saying
that your friends thought
that a trip to Cuba was
just what you needed.
To know that you want to
come & that I cannot, at
once, arrange for your
coming, makes me just
as unhappy as I can be.
Please, when you get this, sweet-
heart, write and decide whetheronce
you will come, & if so, you
can leave New York about
Feb. 1st, & we will remain
till the middle of April- I had
expected to make $250.00 of my
Columbian Salary, but that isn't
really necessary, as we can
get along without it-I want
to do just what you want to do!
Goodnight, you sweet joys! Boo! Boo!
Wednesday morning - 4th- Wake up! You
sleepy girls and get ready for break-
fast- Your old Mr Mantee is
up and ready for his bath, and yet
his girls are still snoring away!
Only about 4 weeks more, and
Papa can start back to see his
precious babies, and won't he be
glad to get back? He is now
counting off the days & if pre-
cious mother doesn't pass him
on the way, he will soon see both
of his fat, sweet children, who
have been so good & sweet since
he left- Take care of your precious
selves, and you must wake up!!
Love & kisses & kisses & love for the
sweetest girls in all the world-
